items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 4pm this afternoon, Friday 25th February, and for at least the following 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Gt Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Gt Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 26th February.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake and river levels remain high, but are now receding on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low lying land will continue to affect areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site over the next few days. We are continuing to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses which may be flooded and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, 26/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Cae Howel & Llanymynech gauges following recent heavy rainfall. No further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. 
Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday night, 20/02/22. 
The current level at the Cae Howel gauge is 5.06m at 3pm on Friday 25/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by midday on Saturday 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse and several flood warnings remain in force, with low lying land most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land in Acaster Malbis, Acaster Selby and Naburn Lock, particularly around high tide times. We are monitoring river levels closely and with no further significant rainfall expected over the coming days, we expect levels to continue to fall slowly towards normal. However, water may remain on low lying land, Ings and washlands for several days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9PM on Friday 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Ouse

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. However, flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse and several flood warnings remain in force, with low lying land most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land in York, and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The Foss Barrier in York is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Clifton Ings is also in operation. No further significant rainfall is expected over the next few days, so we expect the levels to continue to fall towards normal. This message will be updated by 9PM on Friday 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling at all river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Flooding is affecting low lying land & roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Hayes Basin, White Abbey, Leighton, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth & Gravel Hill Lane, Shrewsbury.
Crew Green peaked at 6.63m & Montford peaked at 7.02m Monday evening 21/02/22; Welshbridge peaked at 5.15m Tuesday morning 22/02/22.  Buildwas peaked at 6.6m &  Bridgnorth peaked at 5.1m Wednesday morning 23/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our incident response staff are checking defences. The river level forecasts displayed on GOV.UK are the raw data output from the Forecasting System computer models. These have not had an expert Flood Forecaster adjustment applied. This will sometimes result in slightly different level forecasts between levels provided on GOV.UK and those shown in this message.
This message will be updated by midday 26/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message: River levels remain high and slowly decreasing at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels on the River Dee are continuing to fall steadily. They are expected to remain above Flood Alert levels today, Friday. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane at Farndon may still be affected by standing water which could be deep in places. No significant rainfall is forecast over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 26/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are falling at the Butts Bridge and Ford Bridge river gauges. No further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. Flooding continues. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by midday on Saturday 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high, but are now falling slowly at the Yeaton, Rodington and Tern - Walcot river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
No further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by midday on Saturday 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame and Chalgrove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are still high on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 25/02/2022, especially around the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. 
It is forecast to be dry today and over the weekend. River levels are still high but falling slowly in Stadhampton and Dorchester. Levels are forecast to continue falling but will remain high and out of banks for the next few days. 
Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to be affecting low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye in Derbyshire
items.message: River levels remain high and slowly decreasing at the Ashford river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain throughout today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: Tides are no longer expected to influence river levels at Gloucester and Sandhurst river gauges.  These locations are though being affected by high fluvial levels as a result of river water flowing into the area following recent heavy rainfall upstream.  The Flood Warning for the River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore and a fluvial Flood Alert for the River Severn in Gloucestershire remain in force.  No tidal flooding is expected in other gauge locations. This message will be updated by 7pm tomorrow 26/02/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are still high on the River Ray following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 25/02/2022, in Islip.
It is forecast to be dry today and over the weekend. River levels in Islip are falling and are forecast to continue falling but will remain high and out of banks for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. The areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly due to recent rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
Levels have risen at the Sandhurst river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding is expected today 25/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore and Sandhurst Lane. Base Lane, Sandhurst may also flood and the A417 Over to Maisemore may be close to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.85m to 3.95m this evening, 25/02/22, Gloucester 3.4m to 3.6m this evening, 25/02/22.
    
We expect river levels to remain high overnight and may begin to recede tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Kempsey Village
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is operational. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Lower Teme
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. River levels are now falling at the Ludlow, Tenbury, Knightsford Bridge and Bransford river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme from Ludlow to Bransford. Locations that may be affected include Tenbury Wells and Knightwick.  
Knightsford Bridge peaked at 5.30m early Tuesday morning, 22/02/22, and Bransford peaked at 5.14m on Tuesday morning 22/02/22.
No further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by midday on Saturday 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning. 

Bredon river gauge peaked at 2.84m on Tuesday 22 February.
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect Mill Avon riverside property, minor roads at Tirely, Chaceley, Hasfield, Hawbridge, Lower Lode, Ashleworth, Deerhurst, Wainlode and Apperley. Also affected are properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Access to Abbey Mill is compromised.
The Upper Pound gauge peaked at 4.25m on Thursday afternoon, 24/02/2022 and the Mythe gauge peaked at 4.32 on Thursday afternoon, 24/02/2022.
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 9:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further significant rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.message:
The river level has peaked and is now falling at the Kempsey Yacht Club gauge. Flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect Court Meadow Caravan Park and could affect properties at Lower Ferry Lane, Callow End. 
The Kempsey Yacht Club gauge peaked at 7.05m on Wednesday evening, 23/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.

items.description: River Severn at Pitchcroft, North Worcester
items.message:
River levels have peaked and are falling slowly at the Worcester (Barbourne) river gauge.  Levels remain high due to recent heavy rainfall, consequently flooding of property continues. We expect flooding to affect Waterworks Road properties, Newport Street and Pitchcroft Lane. 
Worcester (Barbourne) river gauge peaked at 5.62m on Wednesday evening, 23/02/2022.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We expect flooding to affect properties at Quay Street, South Quay, Diglis Avenue and Hood Street. Properties also affected at Pitchcroft Lane, Waterworks Road, Newport Street, Croft Road, Diglis Dock Road, Diglis Lane and Diglis Avenue, Worcester including the A44 New Road. 
The Diglis gauge peaked at 5.05m on Wednesday evening, 23/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.

Further rainfall is forecast for Monday, though it is not currently expected that this will lead to the need to re-issue this flood warning.   We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Predicted Peak at Haw Bridge 5.1m to 5.2m on Friday morning, 25/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.

items.description: River Ouse at Naburn Lock
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next few days, and we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9PM on Friday 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. Flooding remains a risk near the River Ouse including properties on King's Staith in York, and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next few days, and we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. The Foss Barrier is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9PM on Friday 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are continuing to fall slowly. Flooding remains a risk near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St George's Field car park and Rowntree Park. Flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is expected. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next few days, and we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. The Foss Barrier is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated by 9pM on Friday 25/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
River levels Saxons Lode river gauge have peaked and are now falling slowly. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect property at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn. Hanley Road is closed. 
The Saxons Lode gauge peaked at 5.33m on Thursday morning, 24/02/2022.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. 
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels have now fallen below levels of concern on the River Ouse between Selby and Faxfleet. There is no longer a threat of flooding. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water in washlands and low-lying land for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Castle, Rectory Road in Upton upon Severn and Saxons Lode
items.message:
River levels at the Saxons Lode river gauge have peaked and are now falling slowly.  Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect property and roads in and around Hanley Castle and Saxons Lode.  
The Saxons Lode gauge peaked at 5.33m on Thursday morning, 24/02/2022.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 9:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Clifton and Severn Stoke
items.message:
River levels have peaked and are falling slowly at the Saxons Lode river gauge. 
We expect river levels to remain high this week, consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Clifton and Severn Stoke.  
The Kempsey Yacht Club gauge peaked at 7.05m on Wednesday evening, 23/02/22.   
The Saxons Lode gauge peaked at 5.33m on Thursday morning, 24/02/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. 
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at East Waterside, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
River levels at the Saxons Lode river gauge have peaked and are now falling slowly.  Consequently, flooding of property and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect properties at East Waterside, Upton upon Severn, the B4211, Malvern Road including Marina road (A4104) in Upton upon Severn.  

The Saxons Lode gauge peaked at 5.33m on Thursday morning, 24/02/2022.   
We expect levels to remain high this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and be prepared to move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 10:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at the Wharfage, Ironbridge
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Ouse at Acaster Selby
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, as flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. High levels on the River Wharfe above Cawood may keep levels high for some days. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next few days, and we expect levels to continue to fall slowly. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Severn at Chaceley and Haw Bridge
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property is expected.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Tirley, Chaceley and Haw Bridge, including the B4213. 
Predicted Peak at Haw Bridge 5.1m to 5.2m on Friday morning, 25/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high into next week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Abbots Court, Deerhurst
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Haw Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property is expected. We expect flooding to affect Abbots Court, Deerhurst. 
Predicted Peak at Haw Bridge 5.1m to 5.2m on Friday morning, 25/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 10:00am on Saturday, 26/02/22, or as the situation changes.
